. However, State of Cities Climate Finance report estimated
that an average of USD 384 billion was invested
in urban climate finance annually in 2017
. The Institute for Environment and Development estimates that out of the 17.4
tments in climate finance, less than 10% (1.5 billion USD) was approved for
focused climate change projects between 2003 and 2016
Subnational climate public and private finance.
among the subnational climate finance landscape
mechanisms that can support climate in
vestment for the urban sector include public
(PPPs); international finance; national investment vehicles; pricing, regulation, standards; land value
capture; debt finance; and fiscal decentralization
(Granoff et al. 2016; Floater et al. 2017b; Gorelick
. Among these mechanisms, PPPs, debt finance, and land value
have the potentials to mobilise private finance
is needed, including those bearing on contracts and regulatory arrangement, to reflect local specificities
[Reference to Public private mobilization Section in 15.6.1.1].
PPPs are particularly important in cities with mature financial systems as th
depends on appropriate investment architecture at scale and government capacity
Such cities can enable its infrastructure such as renewable energy production and distribution, water
ents to generate consumer revenue streams that incentivise private

in private finance by providing early

The use of carbon pricing is increasing at the
subnational level along with regulation and standards on negative externalities, such as pollution, to
and borrowing, including municipal bonds, is another potential
tool for raising upfront capital, especially for rich cities
sovereign, and sovereign bonds could grow over time, given efforts to expand the
and ensure a sufficient supply of own
source revenue to reduce the default risk. As of now, subnational
sovereign bonds are constrained by public finance limits and the fiscal capacities of
governments. However, while green bonds h
ave potential for growth at the subnational level and may
result in a lower cost of capital in some cases, the market faces challenges related to scaling up and has
been associated with limited measurable environmental impact to date (see Section 15.6.8 In
Financial Products for further discussion). Further, bonds with lower credit ratings drive higher issuance
costs for climate risk cities, e.g., costs related to disclosure and reporting
